embroiled.example: These days we are never short of a D.C. politician embroiled in scandal--a welcome phenomenon for those who, having barely finished feasting on the sordid details of one imbroglio, can sink their teeth into a fresh one.

empathetic.example: Most discrimination and hatred is based on a lack of empathetic awareness of people that have the same aspitations and fears.
empathetic.definition: showing understanding and ready comprehension of other peoples' states and emotions

emulate.example: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patterns and intonation of people who speak the language.
emulate.definition: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating; compete with successfully

endemic.example: Irish cuisine makes great use of potatoes, but ironically, the potato is not endemic to Ireland.
endemic.definition: native; originating where it is found

enmity.example: Charles rude remark toward Sarah yesterday was due to his illness, not due to any real enmity toward Sarah.

entice.example: Harold enticed his wife, Maude, to go on a vacation to Hawaii, with promises of luaus on the beach and all-you-can-eat seafood buffets.
entice.definition: get someone to do something through (often false or exaggerated) promises

enumerate.example: I sat and listened as she enumerated all of the things she did not like about the past three months.

err.example: He erred in thinking that "indigent" and "indignant" were synonyms.

errant.example: Unlike his peers, who spent their hours studying in the library, Matthew preferred errant walks through the university campus.
errant.definition: to be wandering; not sticking to a circumscribed path

erratic.example: It came as no surprise to pundits that the President's attempt at re-election floundered; even during his term, support for his policies was erratic, with an approval rating jumping anywhere from 30 to 60 percent.

euphoria.example: The euphoria of winning her first gold medal in the 100 meter dash overwhelmed Shelly-Ann Fraser and she wept tears of immense joy.
euphoria.definition: a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation

evasive.example: Every time I call the bank, I receive the same evasive answers about our mortgage and never get a clear response.

evenhanded.example: Teachers often have trouble being evenhanded to all of their varied students.

exasperate.example: As a child, I exasperated my mother with strings of never-ending questions.

excruciating.example: After the boulder rolled a couple of feet, pinning my friend's arm, he experienced excruciating pain.

exemplify.example: Please present some case studies that exemplify the results that you claim in your paper.
exemplify.definition: clarify by giving an example of

exhort.example: Nelson's parents exhorted him to study medicine, urging him to choose a respectable profession; intransigent, Nelson left home to become a graffiti artist.

extenuating.example: The jury was hardly moved by the man's plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.
extenuating.definition: making less guilty or more forgivable

facetious.example: Facetious behavior will not be tolerated during sex eduation class; it's time for all of you to treat these matters like mature adults.

fawn.example: The media fawned over the handsome new CEO, praising his impeccable sense of style instead of asking more pointed questions.
fawn.definition: try to gain favor by extreme flattery
fawn.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

ferret.example: Ever the resourceful lexicographer, Fenton was able to ferret out the word origin of highly obscure words.
ferret.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

fete.example: After World War II, war heroes were feted at first but quickly forgotten.

fickle.example: She was so fickle in her politics, it was hard to pinpoint her beliefs; one week she would embrace a side, and the next week she would denounce it.
fickle.definition: liable to sudden unpredictable change, esp. in affections or attachments

finagle.example: Steven was able to finagle one of the last seats on the train by convincing the conductor that his torn stub was actually a valid ticket.
finagle.definition: achieve something by means of trickery or devious methods

fledgling.example: Murray has years of experience in family practice, but he is just a fledgling in surgery.
fledgling.definition: young and inexperienced; describing any new participant in some activity

fleece.example: Many people have been fleeced by Internet scams and never received their money back.
fleece.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

flounder.example: Sylvia has excelled at advanced calculus, but ironically, when she has deal with taxes, she flounders.

flush.example: The exam's passage is flush with difficult words, words that you may have learned only yesterday.

foible.example: When their new roommate sat staring at an oak tree for an hour, Marcia thought it indicated a mental problem, but Jeff assured her it was a harmless foible.
foible.definition: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual

foolhardy.example: The police regularly face dangerous situations, so for a police officer not to wear his bullet-proof vest is foolhardy.
foolhardy.definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences

forthright.example: I did not expect the insurance agent to give us any straight answers, but I was pleasent surprised by how forthright he was.
forthright.definition: characterized by directness in manner or speech; without subtlety or evasion

futile.example: I thought I could repair the car myself, but after two days of work with no success, I have to admit that my efforts were futile.
futile.definition: producing no result or effect; unproductive of success

genial.example: Betty is a genial young woman: everyone she meets is put at ease by her elegance and grace.

genteel.example: A live string quartet would provide a more genteel air to the wedding than would a folk singer.
genteel.definition: marked by refinement in taste and manners

glean.example: Herb has given us no formal statement about his background, but from various hints, I have gleaned that he grew up in difficult circumstances.

glib.example: I have found that the more glib the salesman, the worse the product.
glib.definition: (of a person) speaking with ease but without sincerity

goad.example: Doug did not want to enter the race, but Jim, through a steady stream of taunts, goaded him into signing up for it.

grovel.example: Every time Susan comes to the office, Frank grovels as if she were about to fire.

guffaw.example: Whenever the jester fell to the ground in mock pain, the king guffawed, exposing his yellow, fang-like teeth.

hamper.example: As the rain water began to collect in pools on the highway, it began to hamper the flow of traffic.
hamper.definition: prevent the progress or free movement of
hamper.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

hamstrung.example: The FBI has made so many restriction on the local police that they are absolutely hamstrung, unable to accomplish anything.

heyday.example: During the heyday of Prohibition, bootlegging had become such a lucrative business that many who had been opposed to the 18th Amendment began to fear it would be repealed.
heyday.definition: the pinnacle or top of a time period or career

hodgepodge.example: Those in attendance represented a hodgepodge of the city's denizens: chimney sweepers could be seen sitting elbow to elbow with stockbrokers.

hound.example: An implacable foe of corruption, Eliot Ness hounded out graft in all forms--he even helped nab Al Capone.
hound.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

humdrum.example: Having grown up in a humdrum suburb, Jacob relished life in New York City after moving.

illicit.example: Though Al Capone was engaged in many illicit activities, he was finally arrested for income tax evasion, a relatively minor offense.
illicit.definition: contrary to or forbidden by law

immaterial.example: The judge found the defendant's comments immaterial to the trial, and summarily dismissed him from the witness stand.

impeccable.example: He was impeccably dressed in the latest fashion without a single crease or stain.

impede.example: Since the police sergeant had to train the pair of new hires, progress in his own case was impeded.
impede.definition: be a hindrance or obstacle to

impending.example: The impending doom of our world has been a discussed and debated for 2000 years--maybe even longer.
impending.definition: close in time; about to occur

impermeable.example: The sand bags placed on the river formed an impermeable barrier, protecting the town from flooding.
impermeable.definition: does not allow fluids to pass through

implicate.example: The crime boss was implicated for a long list of crimes, ranging from murder to disturbing the peace.
implicate.definition: to indicate in wrongdoing, usually a crime

imponderable.example: According to many lawmakers, the huge variety of factors affecting society make devising an efficient healthcare system an imponderable task.
imponderable.definition: impossible to estimate or figure out

impregnable.example: As a child, Amy would build pillow castles and pretend they were impregnable fotresses.
impregnable.definition: immune to attack; incapable of being tampered with

inadvertent.example: Although Prohibition was rooted in noble ideals, the inadvertent and costly consequences of making alcohol illegal in the U.S. led its the repeal.
inadvertent.definition: happening by chance or unexpectedly or unintentionally

inarticulate.example: Although a brilliant economist, Professor Black was completely inarticulate, a terrible lecturer.
inarticulate.definition: without or deprived of the use of speech or words

incense.example: When Herb bought football tickets for a game on the day of their wedding anniversary, Jill was incensed.
incense.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

incessant.example: I don't mind small children in brief doses, but I think the incessant exposure that their parents have to them would quickly wear me down.
incessant.definition: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing

inclement.example: Marcus Aurelius, though a fair man, was inclement to Christians during his reign, persecuting them violently.
inclement.definition: used of persons or behavior; showing no mercy

incumbent.example: Middle managers at times make important decisions, but real responsibility for the financial well-being of the corporation is ultimately incumbent on the CEO.
incumbent.definition: necessary (for someone) as a duty or responsibility

indict.example: The bankrobber was indicted on several major charges, including possession of a firearm.
indict.definition: to formally charge or accuse of wrong-doing

indigenous.example: The plants and animals indigenous to Australia are notably different from those indigenous to the U.S-- one look at a duckbill platypus and you know you're not dealing with an opossum.

indignant.definition: feeling anger over a perceived injustice

industrious.example: Pete was an industrious student, completing every assignment thoroughly and on time.
industrious.definition: characterized by hard work and perseverance

inflammable.example: It only takes one person to leave an inflammable comment on an Internet thread for that thread to blow up into pages upon pages of reader indignation.

ingenuity.example: Daedalus was famous for his ingenuity; he was able to fashion his son Icarus with a pair of wings, using wax to hold them together.

inkling.example: Lynne speaks four Romance languages, but she doesn't have an inkling about how East Asian languages are structured.
inkling.definition: a slight suggestion or vague understanding

insipid.example: The movie director was known for hiring beautiful actors in order to deflect attention away from the insipid scripts he would typically use.

insolvent.example: With credit card bills skyrocketing, a shockingly large number of Americans are truly insolvent.
insolvent.definition: unable to pay one's bills; bankrupt

intermittent.example: The intermittent thunder continued and the night was punctuated by cracks of lightning--a surreal sleepless night.
intermittent.definition: stopping and starting at irregular intervals

inundate.example: The newsroom was inundated with false reports that only made it more difficult for the newscasters to provide an objective account of the bank robbery.

irascible.example: If Arthur's dog is not fed adequately, he becames highly irascible, even growling at his own shadow.

irk.example: My little sister has a way of irking and annoying me like no other person.

irresolute.example: He stood irresolute at the split in the trail, not sure which route would lead back to the camp.
irresolute.definition: uncertain how to act or proceed

jargon.example: To those with little training in medicine, the jargon of doctors can be very difficult to understand.
jargon.definition: a characteristic language of a particular group

jocular.example: My uncle was always in a jocular mood at family gatherings, messing up people's hair and telling knock- knock jokes to anyone who would listen.
jocular.definition: characterized by jokes and good humor

junta.definition: an aggressive takeover by a group (usually military)

laborious.example: The most laborious job I've had was working 20 hours a day as a fisherman in King Salmon, Alaska.
laborious.definition: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion; especially physical effort

leery.example: Without checking his references and talking  to previous employers, I am leery of hiring the candidate.
leery.definition: openly distrustful and unwilling to confide

lethargic.example: Nothing can make a person more lethargic than a big turkey dinner.

lucid.example: Though Walters writes about physics and time travel, his writing is always lucid, so readers with little scientific training can understand difficult concepts.

macabre.example: Edgar Allen Poe was considered the master of the macabre; his stories vividly describe the moment leading up to--and often those moments after--a grisly death.
macabre.definition: suggesting the horror of death and decay; gruesome

malady.example: The town was struck by a malady throughout the winter that left most people sick in bed for two weeks.

malevolent.example: Villians are known for their malevolent nature, oftentimes inflicting cruetly on others just for enjoyment.
malevolent.definition: wishing or appearing to wish evil to others; arising from intense ill will or hatred

malleable.example: My little brother is so malleable that I can convince him to sneak cookies from the cupboard for me.

malodorous.example: Some thermally active fountains spew sulfur fumes--the air around them is sometimes so malodorous that many have to plug their noses.

martial.example: Americans tend to remember Abraham Lincoln as kindly and wise, not at all martial, despite the fact that he was involved in the fiercest war America has even fought.

maxim.example: Johnson initially suggests that the secret to business can be summarized in a single maxim but then requires a 300-page book to explain exactly what he means.
maxim.definition: a short saying expressing a general truth

meander.example: A casual observer might have thought that Peter was meandering through the city, but that day he was actually seeking out those places where he and his long lost love had once visited.

melancholy.example: Hamlet is a figure of tremendous melancholy: he doesn't have a truly cheerful scene throughout the entire play.

melee.example: After enduring daily taunts about my name, I became enraged and pummeled the schoolyard bully and his sycophantic friends in a brutal melee.
melee.definition: a wild, confusing fight or struggle

mesmerize.example: The plot and the characters were so well developed that many viewers were mesmerized, unable to move their eyes from the screen for even a single second.

misanthrope.example: Hamilton had been deceived so many times in his life that he hid behind the gruff exterior of a misanthrope, lambasting perfect strangers for no apparent reason.

miscreant.example: Come back you miscreant! yelled the woman who just had her purse stollen.
miscreant.definition: a person who breaks the law

miser.example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.
miser.definition: a person who doesn't like to spend money (because they are greedy)

misogynist.example: Many have accused Hemingway of being a quiet misogynist, but recently unearthed letters argue against this belief.
misogynist.definition: a person who dislikes women in particular

moment.example: Despite the initial hullabaloo, the play was of no great moment in Hampton's writing career, and within a few years the public quickly forgot his foray into theater arts.
moment.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

moot.example: Since the Board just terminated Steve as the CEO, what the finance committe might have thought of his proposed marketing plan for next year is now a moot point.
moot.definition: open to argument or debate; undecidable in a meaningless or irrelevant way
moot.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

morose.example: After Stanley found out he was no longer able to go on vacation with his friends, he sat in his room morosely.
morose.definition: ill-tempered and not inclined to talk; gloomy

morph.example: The earnestness of the daytime talk shows of the 1970's has morphed into something far more sensational and vulgar: today guests actually standup and threaten to take swings at one another.
morph.definition: To undergo dramatic change in a seamless and barely noticeable fashion.

muted.example: Helen preferred muted earth colors, such as green and brown, to the bright pinks and red her sister liked.
muted.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obdurate.example: No number of pleas and bribes would get him to change his obdurate attitude.
obdurate.definition: stubbornly persistent in changing an opinion or action

obliging.example: Even after all his success, I found him to be accommodating and obliging, sharing with me his "secret tips" on how to gain wealth and make friends.
obliging.definition: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others

obstinate.example: The coach suggested improvements Sarah might make on the balance beam, but she remained obstinate, unwilling to modify any of the habits that made her successful in the past.
obstinate.definition: resistant to guidance or discipline; stubbornly persistent

ornate.example: The ornate Victorian and Edwardian homes spread throughout San Francisco are my favorite part of the city.
ornate.definition: marked by elaborate rhetoric and elaborated with decorative details

paradoxical.example: That light could be both a particle and a wave seems paradoxical, but nonetheless, it is true.
paradoxical.definition: seemingly contradictory but nonetheless possibly true

pastoral.example: Those who imagine America's countryside as a pastoral region are often disappointed to learn that much of rural U.S. is filled with cornfields extending as far as the eye can see.
pastoral.definition: relating to the countryside in a pleasant sense

patronize.example: She says she genuinely wanted to help me, but instead she patronized me, constantly pointing out how I was inferior to her.
patronize.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

paucity.example: There is a paucity of jobs hiring today that require menial skills, since most jobs have either been automated or outsourced.

peevish.example: Our office manager is peevish, so the rest of us tip-toe around him, hoping not to set off another one of his fits.

perennial.example: Even at the old-timers games, Stan Musial would get the loudest cheer: he was a perennial favorite of the fans there.
perennial.definition: lasting an indefinitely long time; eternal; everlasting
perennial.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

perpetuate.example: If you do not let him do things for himself, you are merely perpetuating bad habits that will be even harder to break in the future.

perquisite.example: Even as the dishwasher at the French restaurant, Josh quickly learned that he had the perquisite of being able to eat terrific food for half the price diners would pay.
perquisite.definition: a right reserved exclusively by a particular person or group (especially a hereditary or official right)

pertinent.example: While the salaries of the players might draw attention in the media, such monetary figures are not pertinent to the question of who plays the best on the field.
pertinent.definition: having precise or logical relevance to the matter at hand

perturb.example: Now that Henry is recovering from a major illnesses, he no longer lets the little trivialities, such as late mail, perturb him.
perturb.definition: disturb in mind or cause to be worried or alarmed

peruse.example: Instead of perusing important documents, people all too often rush to the bottom of the page and plaster their signatures at the bottom.

pine.example: Standing forlornly by the window, she pined for her lost love.
pine.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pinnacle.example: At its pinnacle, the Roman Empire extended across most of the landmass of Eurasia, a feat not paralleled to the rise of the British Empire in the 18th and 19th century.

piquant.example: The chef, with a mere flick of the salt shaker, turned the bland tomato soup into a piquant meal.

pithy.example: I enjoy reading the Daodejing for its pithy and insightful prose; it always gives me something to think about.

pittance.example: Vinny's uncle beamed smugly about how he'd offered his nephew fifty dollars for his Harvard tuition; even twice the amount would have been a mere pittance.

placid.example: Doug is normally placid, so we were all shocked to see him yelling at the television when the Mets lost the game.

plodding.example: Charlie may seem to run at a plodding pace, but he is an ultramarathoner, meaning he runs distances of up to 100 miles, and can run for ten hours at a stretch.

ploy.example: Dennis arranged an elaborate ploy, involving 14 different people lying for him in different situations, so that it could appear that he was meeting Mary completely by chance at the wedding reception.
ploy.definition: a clever plan to turn a situation to one's advantage

powwow.example: Before the team takes the field, the coach always calls for a powwow so that he can make sure all the players are mentally in the right place.

precarious.example: People smoke to relax and forget their cares, but ironically, in terms of health risks, smoking is far more precarious than either mountain-climbing or skydiving.

precedent.example: The principal explained that even though one student had done modelling work outside of school, the outfits that student wore in those photographs in no way established a precedent for what could be worn at school dances.
precedent.definition: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences at a later time

preempt.example: A governmental warning about an imminent terrorist attack would preempt ordinary network programming on television.
preempt.definition: take the place of or have precedence over

preemptive.example: Just as Martha was about to take the only cookie left on the table, Noah preemptively swiped it.
preemptive.definition: done before someone else can do it

presumption.example: The new neighbor quickly gained a reptuation for her presumption; she had invited herself to several of the neighbors homes, often stopping over at inopportune times and asking for a drink.
presumption.definition: audacious (even arrogant) behavior that you have no right to

presumptuous.example: Many felt that Barney was presumptuous in moving into the large office before the management even made any official announcement of his promotion.

prevail.example: Before the cricket match, Australia was heavily favored, but India prevailed.

pristine.example: Drill sergeants are known for demanding pristine cabinets, uniforms, and beds, and often make new recruits clean and clean and clean until they meet the expected high standards.

profuse.example: During mile 20 of the Hawaii Marathon, Dwayne was sweating so profusely that he stopped to take off his shirt, and ran the remaining six miles wearing nothing more than skimpy shorts.

profusion.example: When Maria reported that she had been visited by Jesus Christ and had proof, a profusion of reporters and journalists descended on the town.

proponent.example: Ironically, the leading proponent of Flat-Earth Theory flies all over the world in an effort to win more adherents.

provisional.example: Until the corporate office hands down a definitive decision on use of the extra offices, we will share their use in a provisional arrangement.

pugnacious.definition: eager to fight or argue; verbally combative

qualm.example: While he could articulate no clear reason why Harkner's plan would fail, he neverless felt qualms about committing any resources to it.

quandary.example: Steve certainly is in a quandary: if he doesn't call Elaine, she will blame him for everything, but if he does call her, the evidence of where he currently is could cost him his job.

raffish.example: The men found him raffish, but the women adored his smart clothes and casual attitude.

raft.example: Despite a raft of city ordinances passed by an overzealous council, noise pollution continued unabated in the megalopolis.
raft.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

rakish.example: As soon as he arrived in the city, the rakish young man bought some drugs and headed straight for the seedy parts of town.

rankle.example: His constant whistling would rankle her, sometimes causing her to leave in a huff.

rash.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

redress.example: Barry forgot his wife's birthday two years in a row, and was only able to redress his oversight by surprising his wife with a trip to Tahiti.

redress.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

relegate.example: When Dexter was unable to fulfill his basic duties, instead of firing him, the boss relegated him to kitchen cleanup.

remiss.example: Remiss in his duty to keep the school functioning efficiently, the principle was relieved of his position after only three months.

renege.example: We will no longer work with that vendor since it has reneged on nearly every agreement.

replete.example: Only weeks after the hurricane made landfall, the local supermarket shelves were replete with goods, so quick was the disaster relief response.
replete.definition: completely stocked or furnished with something

reprobate.example: Those old reprobates drinking all day down by the river--they are not going to amount to much.

reservation.example: I was initially excited by the idea of a trip to Washington, D.C.  but now that I have read about the high crime statistics there, I have some reservations.

reservation.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

resignation.example: Since Jack could not think of a convincing reason why he had to miss the seminar, he attended it with a sense of resignation.
resignation.definition: the acceptance of something unpleasant that can't be avoided
resignation.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

resolve.example: After much thought, Ted resolved not to travel abroad this summer because he didn't have much money in his bank account.

respite.example: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.

retiring.example: Nelson was always the first to leave soirees--rather than mill about with "fashionable" folk, he was retiring, and preferred the solitude of his garret.

retract.example: Email is wonderfully efficient, but once something awkward or damaging has been sent, there is no way to retract it.

rile.example: Dan is usually calm and balanced, but it takes only one intense glare from Sabrina to rile him.

robust.example: Chris preferred bland and mild beers, but Bhavin preferred a beer with more robust flavor.

sanguine.example: With the prospect of having to learn 3,000 words during the course of the summer, Paul was anything but sanguine.

savvy.example: With his savvy business partner, the company was able to turn a profit within a year.

scintillating.example: Richard Feynman was renowned for his scintillating lectures--the arcana of quantum physics was made lucid as he wrote animatedly on the chalkboard.

screed.example: Joey had difficulty hanging out with his former best friend Perry, who, during his entire cup of coffee, enumerated all of the government's deficiencies--only to break ranks and launch into some screed against big business.

sentimental.example: I don't like romanticism for the same reason I don't like melodramatic acting and soap operas--overly sentimental.

serendipity.definition: the instance in which an accidental, fortunate discovery is made

serene.example: I'd never seen him so serene; usually, he was a knot of stress and anxiety from hours of trading on the stock exchange.

slapdash.example: The office building had been constructed in a slapdash manner, so it did not surprise officials when, during a small earthquake, a large crack emerged on the faÃ§ade of the building.

smattering.example: I know only a smattering of German, but Helen is able to read German newspapers and converse with natives.
smattering.definition: a slight or superficial understanding of a subject; a small amount of something

smug.example: When Phil was dating the model, he had a smug attitude that annoyed his buddies.

snide.example: The chairman interpreted Taylor's question about promotions as a snide remark, but in all innocence Taylor was trying to figure out the company's process.

snub.example: Wheeler was completely qualified for the committee, but the board snubbed him, choosing an obviously lesser qualified candidate instead.

start.example: All alone in the mansion, Henrietta started when she heard a sound.

start.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

steadfast.example: A good captain needs to be steadfast, continuing to hold the wheel and stay the course even during the most violent storm.

stem.example: To stem the tide of applications, the prestigious Ivy requires that each applicant score at least 330 on the Revised GRE.

stipend.example: He was hoping for a monthly allowance loan from the government, but after no such stipend was forthcoming he realized he would have to seek other means of paying for his college tuition.

stolid.example: Elephants may appear stolid to casual observers, but they actually have passionate emotional lives.

stymie.example: The engineers found their plans stymied at every turn and were ultimately able to make amlost no progress on the project.
stymie.definition: hinder or prevent the progress or accomplishment of

surly.example: Every morning, Bhavin was a surly unhappy person, but once he ate breakfast, he became loving, laughing, and a joy to be around.

tact.example: In a tremendous display of tact, Shelly was able to maintain a strong friendship with Marcia, even though Marcia's husband, Frank, confessed to finding Shelley more attractive than Marcia.

tarnish.example: Pete Rose was one of the best baseball players of his generation, but his involvement with gambling on baseball games has tarnished his image in the eyes of many.

taxing.example: The hike to the summit of Mt. Whitney was so taxing that I could barely speak or stand up.
taxing.extra: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

telling.example: Her unbecoming dress was very telling when it came to her sense of fashion.

tender.example: The government was loath to tender more money in the fear that it might set off inflation.

thoroughgoing.example: As a thoroughgoing bibliophile, one who had turned his house into a veritable library, he shocked his friends when he bought a Kindle.

thrifty.example: He was economical, spending his money thriftily and on items considered essential.

thwart.example: I wanted to spend a week in New York this autumn, but the high costs of travel and lodging thwarted my plans.
thwart.definition: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of

tout.example: At the conference, the CEO touted the extraordinary success of his company's Research & Development division.

travail.example: While they experienced nothing but travails in refinishing the kitchen, they completed the master bedroom in less than a weekend.

uncanny.example: Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.

unconscionable.example: The lawyer's demands were so unconscionable that rather than pay an exorbitant sum or submit himself to any other inconveniences, the defendant decided to find a new lawyer.

underwrite.example: The latest symphony broadcast was made possible with underwriting from the Carnegie Endowment.

aplomb.example: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations--she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.

arch.example: The baroness was arch, making playful asides to the townspeople; yet because they couldn't pick up on her dry humor, they thought her supercilious.

arriviste.example: The city center was aflutter with arrivistes who each tried to outdo one another with their ostentatious sports cars and chic evening dress.

artless.example: Despite the president's seemingly artless speeches, he was a skilled and ruthless negotiator.

catholic.example: Jonah's friends said that Jonah's taste in music was eclectic; Jonah was quick to point out that not only was his taste eclectic but it was also catholic: he enjoyed music from countries as far-flung as Mali and Mongolia.

cede.example: Eventually, all parents must cede control of their growing childrens' educations and allow their offspring some autonomy.

celerity.example: We aim to respond to customers' questions with celerity and accuracy, with no longer than a 24 hour wait time.

chagrin.example: She never cared what others said about her appearance but was chagrined by the smallest comment from her mother.

chimera.example: Many believe that a world free of war is a chimera--a dream that ignores humanity's violent tendancies.

crestfallen.example: I asked Maria on a date and she refused without a moment's thought; I was crestfallen.
